In regard to #3 my opinion of pioneer doctors, both Dr. Bird and Dr. Porter were very competent. Dr. Godin was soon said to be extremely callow and incompetent so much so an investigation was made and a strong petition, backed by actual experiences, was sent to the Government to remove him but it failed to accomplish anything. I never used them or his two predecessors.

After Dr. Lavallee died the municipality took over and we have Municipal Doctor since then. Some good one or two indifferent but since the railroad came in they have always been another doctor in neighboring villages. I cannot think of trouble we have no doctor here in Wellm Bank for the last three weeks, at the nearest village Coronach.

In regard to Mr. H. & my friend, Dr. Bird and Dr. Conner, who are very competent to go further in this case and to continue the investigation. No need for an immediate call and immediate action was made and a strong petition should be addressed to Governor to remove him. It behooves us all to accept any offer. Let me know what he is doing.

Dr. Lawrence died in a hospital in New York City and was buried Municipal Cemetery. He died there. His death came on his way home from a dinner in neighboring villages until his death was less than two weeks, or no news without personal.
In regard to #3 my opinion of pioneer doctors. Both Dr. Bird and Dr. Penton were very competent but Dr. Godin was soon said to be extremely callous and incompetent so much so an investigation was made and a strong petition backed by actual experience was sent to the Government to remove him but it failed to accomplish anything. I never used him at his hospital.

After Dr. Lavellee died the municipality took over and we have Municipal Doctors since then some good one or two or different but since the railroad came in they have always been another doctor in neighboring villages. (Until this Dr. Smith we have no doctor here in Wellin Bend for the last three weeks, or the nearest village Cornwall.)

I. Services of a Doctor

1. How far were you from the nearest doctor at first? About 8 miles.

2. Was there one closer as time went by? (Explain the circumstances)

3. What was your opinion of the competence of the pioneer doctor in your district? (a good physician? a good surgeon? Explain why.)
   - Good doctor. English trained. American graduate.
   - In 1907-16 English doctor P.E. Bird. American Dr. Plinton.
   - In 1912 O.J. Gordon came & William Rand & Co. were also physicians.

4. Was it customary to go to the same (or family) doctor in all situations, or did it depend on the nature of the illness?
   - The same.

5. Was the doctor consulted at his office or called to your home? (Explain the circumstances).
   - Generally called to home.

6. What conditions were usually treated without reference to a doctor, and which were of a nature that led to consultation?
   - Sprains.

7. Do you recall how much you paid for doctors' calls or services?
   - Preserved on last page.

What did this amount to annually for yourself? for your family?

Dr. Godin

Never until 1936.

$25.00

11. For what illnesses were members of your family confined to bed at home?
Cold

Generally

Two extremely competent midwives.

13. In the case of contagious diseases, were sick members isolated from the rest of the family? How was this carried out?
No experience with contagious disease.

14. Were children born at home or did the mother go to hospital?
Generally at home

Around here both a doctor and midwife. Doctor.

III. Home Remedies.

15. What home remedies did you use for various illnesses? (Specify illnesses and the treatment given).
   We had our own outlet for birds etc.

16. How did you learn of these remedies? (Specify the remedy and state if it was handed down in the family, recommended by a neighbour, etc.) Were any remedies acquired from the Indians or from people of a particular national background? (Use back of page or extra sheets if necessary).
   The outlet recipe was handed down in the family for many years, but the main ingredient is no longer available. It was a mixture of herbs and spices.

17. What patent medicines were customarily used in your family and for what conditions?
   Bucan pills
   Baby's own tablets

18. What serious accidents (burns, sprains, fractures, etc.) were experienced by members of your family and what treatment was given?
   I have been exceptionally fortunate except for confinement. I had a broken ankle in 1944 and then again two years ago in 1956 when my wife had a broken leg - treated by hospital. She was confined to bed for several weeks.

38. Add any personal experiences, recollections or observations related to this topic which have not been touched in the questionnaire. (Use back of page or extra sheets if necessary).

Medical care around my own district was taken care of by Dr. P.S. Burt M.R.C.S. He came to Canada to work from New England between Canada and England so he could not be called for his services so he attended whenever called and was very kind. When someone was sent to do his work while he attended my family and I attended him back continuously. Dr. Lavallee was a really competent doctor came here in about 1917 and when Dr. Bird left (overseas) I used this doctor for a number of years. His name was Dr. Lavallee.
